notes: On 27 January 2021, leaders from the Leapi Pako clan and the Leapi Pende clan signed a peace agreement in Mt. Kare (Enga). The conditions of the agreement included the following: (1) that all hired fighters shall return immediately to their respective provinces of origin; (2) that the Porgera district law and order mediation team shall mediate disputes regarding settlements; (3) that the two clans shall abide by any decisions made by the said mediation team, and in the event of a disagreement, follow appeal processes; and (4) persons who breach the peace agreement shall incur penalties including a fine of K2000 or a two-year imprisonment. The fighting between the two clans had originated from a land dispute in the Paiela area on 29 November 2017, and extended into the neighboring Porgera valley causing casualties, displacement of persons and property destruction.

notes: Displacement: Around 26 October 2021 (week of), around 180 West Papuan refugees crossed the border from Indonesia to Papua New Guinea and entered Tumolbil (Sandaun). According to Amnesty International, the influx in refugees occurred after a retaliatory attack by Indonesian security forces on rebel militia groups in the Intan Jaya regency on 26 October 2021. Additionally, RNZ has reported that Indonesian forces have targeted suspected village strongholds of the OPM-Free Papua Movement's military wing, and that conflicts in October have spiked in the Bintang Mountains regency, which is closer to the border with Papua New Guinea. According to an OPM spokesperson, soldiers from OPM and TPN (Liberation Army) have confirmed that 47 refugee families have entered Tumolbil. In Tumolbil, locals have confirmed that border crossings by West Papuan refugees had increased since October. According to a Telefomin district police officer, 500 to 600 West Papuan villagers, including mothers and children, are in the jungle in Kiwirok, Indonesia, and still on their way to Papua New Guinea.

notes: Security measures: On 10 January 2022, Milne Bay provincial government in Alotau (Milne Bay) announced a one-month curfew throughout the province in order to prevent gang violence following the killing of a well-known gang leader, Tommy Baker, restricting movement of people on land and sea. A curfew in Alotau begins from 12 am to 5 am while it starts from 10 pm to 5 am in the rest of the province. A curfew on traveling on the sea starts from 6 pm to 5 am. The decision to implement a curfew was made by the provincial law and order committee during a meeting on 4 January 2022. The curfew regarding sea movement was also motivated by concerns about dangerous weather conditions and sea piracy.

Security measures: On 14 January 2022, Papua New Guinea imposed a nationwide ban on public gatherings of more than 100 people to stop the spread of the coronavirus, as announced by the Controller of the National Pandemic Response in Port Moresby (National Capital District). The ban will remain effective until 1 March 2022.

notes: On 7 February 2022, Goilala and Wanigela settlers fought each other using firearms, rocks and other projectiles at Koki market in Port Moresby (National Capital District). One youth was killed, 5 were severely injured from bullet wounds, 17 suffered minor injuries, vehicles were stoned and local businesses and Koki primary school were closed. Three alternative trigger events were alleged to be the cause of this clash. First, that Goilala youths had attempted to carjack a taxi driver and Wanigela youths responsible for maintaining security in the market intervened to defend the taxi driver. Alternatively, that the taxi driver had triggered the violence when he attacked a security guard with a knife after he was told that he was not allowed to park his taxi in the Koki market carpark, leading to the intervention of Wanigelas, who were defending the security guard, and Goilalas who were defending the taxi driver. The third alleged trigger event was that Wanigelas had attacked a Goilala market vendor, causing the intervention of others into the conflict.

Fighting between the two clans began in March 2021 at Kairik, due to claims of outstanding compensation payments and land issues, leading to the killing of close to 100 people.

The conflict was started by a drunken brawl among youths in the Sugu Valley, which escalated into battles between the 3-in-1 group, a coalition of the Perepe, Wambe and Lauwere tribal groups from the Sugu Valley, and the 6-in-1 group, a coalition of the Kambiya, Rearepa, Koyari, Ya'ala, Hurupa and Yatupa tribal groups from the Sugu Valley. The conflict resulted in 30 deaths, the destruction of public and private properties, the closure of health centers and schools, and the displacement of thousands of villagers in the Sugu Valley.

Around 15 April 2022 (month of), members of a clan (likely Rongo clan members-coded as Rongo tribe-based on the rifle that was used in an earlier attack) set fire to a house belonging to a rival clan in West New Britain (likely near Waganakai village, Tabekemeli, based on previous incidents in the area; event coded at Tabekemeli). On 15 April 2022, evictees from Gigo and Laleki settlements, which surround Kimbe, fought among themselves inside Laleki settlement (coded to Kimbe, West New Britain), leading to injuries, looting, and torched homes. On 16 April 2022, a confrontation between two men over a betel nut precipitated several hours of rioting by about 500 local youths in the town center of Kundiawa (Chimbu). Initially, youths from Kundiawa's northside fought youths from Kundiawa's southside. Following cessation of the fight, the two factions looted alcohol from stores and threw stones at passing vehicles. The riot caused locals to flee from the town center, the closure of seven stores, and traffic disruptions until police re-established public order. According to police, there were no major casualties, and damage to shops was minimal.

On 16 April 2022, for the second consecutive day, the evicted settlers of Gigo and Laleki fought among themselves and rioted in Laleki settlement in Kimbe (West New Britain), resulting in two killed, many injured, and 14 homes torched. On 18 April 2022, police responded with the mass arrest of 167 suspects in relation to the riots.

On 18 April 2022, Christians from 10 different denominations marched in Mount Hagen (Western Highlands) to encourage the public to maintain peace and order in the city. The march was organized by the Ministers Fraternal Body of Christ group.

The retaliation by Nordup youths was due to a robbery committed by youth settlers in Matalau against one of the Nordup ward settlers (coded separately).

notes: On 12 May 2022, locals staged a protest in Wabag (Enga) calling for the Electoral Commission to revoke the appointment of their electorate's returning officer for this year's general electorate due to a conflict of interest.

On 14 May 2022, armed men from the Aiyala clan shot and killed three Nomali men and severely injured two Nomali men in Paiam Town (Enga). The Nomali men were attacked while salvaging their belongings from a lodge burnt earlier during the fight between Aiyala and Nomali clans from 7 - 9 May. On 17 May, community leaders of the three Nomali men killed agreed not to retaliate and to allow for the authorities to charge the perpetrators at a peace negotiation meeting in Porgera.

On 20 May 2022, supporters of a candidate for the Popondetta Open electorate in the upcoming national election attacked supporters of a rival candidate running for the same electorate who were travelling in a convoy along the Oro Bay Highway in Jonita, Isuga (Oro), resulting in a child, a woman and a man injured, and three vehicles damaged.

On 25 May 2022, a group of residents demonstrated at Section A in East Taraka, Lae (Morobe) calling for the power management authority to rectify a two-month power outage caused by a blown transformer in March which had impacted more than 1,000 residents.

On 26 May 2022, rioters supporting rival election candidates clashed on the Highlands highway in Munum (Morobe), leaving two men shot dead, several people injured, and the torching of market houses and a vehicle. Police confirmed that the violence was related to the upcoming general election, however, the reason for the outbreak of violence is still unclear.

However, according to police, the Okapa MP was attacked by his supporters, who also burnt down the 5 vehicles, four of which belonged to him. Police were able to escort the Okapa MP to safety, and no injuries were announced by police.

On 2 June 2022, unknown assailants attempted to assassinate a Southern Highlands regional candidate (People's National Congress) for the upcoming general election in Poroma (Southern Highlands). A shot was fired and the bullet hit the candidate's car door. The candidate escaped uninjured.

On 5 June 2022, three assailants fired 6 shots into a vehicle driven by the Returning Officer for Kompiam-Ambum in the upcoming national election at Ambum Bridge near Lakemanda (Wabag). The Returning Officer suffered two pellet wounds to his head and chest but is in a stable condition. Police say no motive has been established yet and investigations are continuing.

Change to armed group: Around 24 June 2022 (as reported), an unknown armed group was discovered being formed in Hela province (coded to Tari). On 18 June 2022, Papua New Guinea military forces uncovered military uniforms in the process of being chartered on a plane from Port Moresby to Hela. A photo showing several men in military fatigues taken on 18 June 2022 was also discovered. The Peoples United Assembly (PUA) has stated that three plane chartered deliveries have been made to Hela containing security gear, election run and kits, and called on police to carry out a thorough investigation into them. Reports from Hela also indicate that the unknown armed group will attempt to take charge of national election polling in Hela.

source: AFP; AP; Australian Broadcasting Corporation News; FBC News; PNG Today; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Elections/referendum: On 4 July 2022, the first day of a three-week polling period for Papua New Guinea's general election was held across parts of Papua New Guinea (coded to Port Moresby). More than 3,600 candidates ran for Papua New Guinea's 118-member Parliament. The leading contenders to lead the new government were current Prime Minister James Marape (PP) and his predecessor Peter O'Neill (PNC). Vote counting was initially mandated to finish on 29 July 2022. However, the Governor-general intervened to extend the period until 5 August 2022 due to delays caused by election-related violence at vote counting centers. On 9 August 2022, incumbent Prime Minister James Marape (PP) was sworn in for a second consecutive term, having secured the support of a majority of the elected members of parliament. On 23 February 2023, the Special Parliamentary Committee on Election Review received a submission from Transparency International Papua New Guinea that close to 30 per cent of elected members were elected through unlawful conduct.

On 5 July 2022, supporters of an independent candidate for the Margarima Open electorate engaged in a fight with supporters of the incumbent MP for the Margarima Open electorate (PANGU) at a polling station in Yambaraka (Hela), resulting in 1 being dead. Homes were also burned.

On 6 July 2022, supporters of an independent candidate for the Margarima Open electorate engaged in a fight with supporters of the incumbent MP for the Margarima Open electorate (PANGU) at a polling station in Yambaraka (Hela), resulting in 2 people being dead. Homes were also burned.
Around 6 July 2022 (week of), supporters of rival election candidates clashed and burned a a polling center and houses in Margarima (Hela). There were no casualties.

On 6 July 2022, around 30 voters from the Hela regional electorate and the Tari-Pori Open electorate protested in front of the police station in Tari (Hela) calling for the 7 ballot boxes collected from polling in Tagali to be declared disputed claiming that they were not allowed to vote on 4 July 2022.

Displacement: On 13 October 2022, around 11,000 people were evicted by police from Morata One in Port Moresby (National Capital District) following a court order which found the informal squatters settlement to be illegal. Three people were injured during the eviction. The settlers had purchased parcels of land from people who were believed to be the customary land owners and accused the government of failing to supply adequate housing in the area, which thus displaced people to informal settlements such as Morata One.

On 13 October 2022, representatives of the Nomali and Kungurine clans agreed to cease fighting and end their occupation of homes in Paiam in a meeting held in Lagaip-Porgera (Enga). The ceasefire was initiated by the Porgera-Paiela Open electorate MP, who is also a Porgera gold mine landowner, in order to allow for the reopening of the Porgera gold mine.

Around 15 October 2022 (weekend of), youths armed with bush knives and wire catapults clashed at the Nuigo settlement in Wewak (East Sepik), leading to two people killed, three people, including a visiting priest, injured, houses torched and hundreds displaced. The settlement allegedly hosted people from almost all six districts of East Sepik, which suggests that the youths might come from different communities.

They beat the old woman, dragging out of her home where they cut off her hand and head with a bush knife. The old woman's relatives tried to intervene but failed. On 16 November 2022 (as reported), police arrested and charged the main suspect with one count of murder. On 3 August 2023 (as reported), police arrested and charged another suspect with murder.

On 20 October 2022, members of two families within Woyoepa (Wayoepa) village signed a peace agreement at Woyoepa (Wayoepa) village, West Okapa (Wayoepa, Okapa, Eastern Highlands), ending a conflict that began in March following the death of a family member, resulting in sorcery accusations being made, and properties set ablaze. The agreement, prepared by the local peace mediation committee and witnessed by church representatives, village court officials, LLG presidents, and police officers, formalized reconciliation between the two families. The peace pact allowed around 600 people to resettle safely in Woyoepa village and committed the parties to coexist peacefully, maintain order, and respect law and security going forward.

It continued for 8 months resulting in 5 Lewa and 2 Wiya men killed, and schools, staff homes and aid posts torched.

On 4 January 2023, Waka tribesmen attacked the Wika tribe in Nondugl 1 (Jiwaka) killing four in retaliation for the killing of a Waka tribesman on 1 January during an ongoing dispute between the two tribes over a stolen pig. The ongoing tribal flight has led to 7 deaths.

Around 4 January 2023 (week of), women advocacy groups including the Porgera District Women Association and Porgera Women in Business demonstrated at the Porgera Development Authority office in Porgera (Enga) calling on the government to restore essential services including Paiam Hospital, Porgera Secondary and Primary Schools, judicial services and the district administration, and for Barrick (Niugini) Limited to reopen the Porgera Gold Mine.

Around 5 January 2023 (as reported), relatives of a deceased young man killed a man who performed circumcision on the deceased young man at Savia village in Sialum (Morobe). The relatives accused the victim of practicing sorcery on the deceased young man, resulting in his death. Police have arrested three suspects and will charge them with murder and manslaughter.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 6 January 2023, protesters demonstrated in Porgera (Enga) protesting Barrick (Niugini) Limited, the operator of the Porgera Gold Mine, over its current recruitment process which they claim has not employed locals within the special mining lease area.

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-); Students (Papua New Guinea); Women (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Around 9 January 2023 (as reported), mothers, Kerowagi police, students, Manda Peace mediators, and community leaders marched for peace at Kerowagi, Chimbu (coded to Yopa ward) in a demonstration organized by the Kup Women for Peace organization. The purpose for the march was to bring support to women, girls and children who were affected and displaced by tribal fighting.

On 10 January 2023, bus drivers and their crew of the Gordon to Manu route enacted a strike and gathered along Waigani Drive in Port Moresby (National Capital District) demanding an explanation from police who ordered them to relocate their pick-up point to Unagi field as part of an initiative to clean up the shopping area at Gordon.

Around 11 January 2023 (week of), relatives of a deceased Barola man set up roadblocks along the Highlands Highway at Barola (Eastern Highlands) in retaliation of his death. The relatives stopped people from Jiwaka and Western Highlands at the roadblocks and harassed them. The deceased was killed in a car accident on 9 January 2023 when he collided with an off duty policeman attached with Jiwaka police who was under the influence of alcohol.

On 11 January 2023, eight armed men killed and robbed a school teacher travelling on a bus after setting up a roadblock near Kopiago (Hela). Police state that although the murder was not related to the current active fight between Wakira and Kanimu clans, the perpetrators are known clan members and are taking refuge among the clans. As a result, a planned peace agreement between Wakira and Kanimu clans has been postponed until the murderers are surrendered to police.

On 12 January 2023, a fight broke out among armed men at Bumbu Settlement on the outskirts of Lae (Morobe) causing one death and severe injuries to others. The fight was a continuation of a conflict within Bumbu Settlement that began in 2022. Police have arrested 6 suspects in relation to the fight.

assoc_actor_2: Yalingin Tribal Group (Papua New Guinea); Wangins Tribal Group (Papua New Guinea); Tangaip Tribal Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 13 January 2023, the Pinai, Yalingin, Wangins, and Tangaip tribal groups held a peace agreement ceremony at Kompiam district, Enga (coded at Kompiam Stat.), in which the Pinai under its leader Amaiu agreed to pay compensation and return land to the other groups. The conflict began in 2019 when a man from Walumin village was murdered on Pinai land, causing Yalingin, Wangins and Tangaip men to attack the Pinai men, with the conflict intensifying further in 2022 due to election-related violence.

Around 15 January 2023 (month of), villagers beat and tortured five women for 11 hours accusing them of practicing sorcery to kill a young man who was the stepson of one of the accused women in Kandep (Enga). One woman was rescued and the other four are still missing.

Strikes: Around 20 January 2023 (from 17 - 20 January), more than 470 health workers as members of the Allied Health Workers Association held a sit-in strike nationwide demanding action be taken by the Department of Health to address the failure to implement industry award wages, resulting in K12.5 million in non compliance claims (coded to Port Moresby, National Capital District).

notes: On 24 January 2023, the Sangu tribe allied with the Mun and Malee tribes attacked people using axes, bush knives and firearms in Tole village in Wabag, Enga, killing 11 villagers and kidnapping 11 children. Among the 11 dead, eight were from Kumbin, a sub-clan of Piau tribe, two were from Kamanwan tribe and one was from the Porealin tribe. The attack was in retaliation for the killing of two men from the Sangu tribe, however the Kumbin tribe is a sub-clan of the Piau Kaimangun tribe but was not involved in the attack. On 25 January police were able to rescue the 11 children in Ambun Valley.

On 28 January 2023, Pari villagers erected a roadblock protesting the arrest of a local man suspected of torching homes in Pari, a village of Port Moresby (National Capital District). Police ordered the suspect's family and friends to remove the roadblock following complaints from the travelling public. After the protesters did not move the roadblock, the police removed it themselves the next day.
On 28 January 2023, sitting MPs, the provincial administration and members of the public walked for peace in opposition to violence and criminal activities in Kokopo (East New Britain).

According to police officers in Western province, this gang is from Komo in Hela province and is involved in kidnapping foreign workers at remote logging operations as well as smuggling guns and drugs along the Papua New Guinea-Australian Border.

Other: On 12 February 2023, two men attacked and chopped a man's hands in Suadogum (East Sepik). The victim was hit by an oncoming vehicle and died when he tried to escape the attack. The attack followed an ongoing feud between the suspect and the deceased. Relatives of the deceased then torched 8 houses and a church in the suspect's village in retaliation of his death (coded separately). On 27 February 2023 (as reported), police apprehended the suspect.

On 13 February 2023, students of Hagen Park Secondary staged a peaceful protest in Mount Hagen (Western Highlands), demanding the resumption of schooling and the return of former deputy principal. Classes in the school were cancelled pending a review of the former deputy principal, while schools throughout the country were now in the third week of schooling.

On 13 February 2023, Wika and Waka tribes signed a ceasefire agreement to ensure peace and free movement in the area in Nondugl 1 (Jiwaka). The agreement has 4 terms: allow movement of people, no firing of weapons or instigation of fights, compensation of families of the deceased, and surrender suspects involved in the fight. On 4 January 2023, Waka tribesmen killed four members of the Wika tribe in Nondugl 1, in retaliation for the killing of a Waka tribesman on 1 January during an ongoing dispute between the two tribes over a stolen pig.

On 14 February 2023, settlers from Bumbu settlement rallied and called for a stop to ongoing violence in Lae (Morobe). Prior to the rally, communal militias in the Bumbu settlement from Gegerobi, Korogu and Angrima had announced before representatives from the police, defense forces, Morobe government, and other stakeholders that they were laying down their arms and wanted peace.
Around 15 February 2023 (week of), relatives of a deceased Suadogum man torched 8 houses and a church near Kininien (East Sepik) in retaliation of his death (coded separately).

Around 15 February 2023 (week of), relatives of a primary school teacher who died earlier in February tortured an elderly man they accused of killing the teacher using sorcery in Gaulim (East New Britain). The relatives tied the elderly man to a chair, doused him with petrol and attempted to set him on fire however police arrived and stopped the attack.

Police arrested the suspects the next day and said they were suspected to have been intoxicated at the time of the incident. In retaliation, the bus owner and his clansmen engaged in a stone-throwing battle with the suspects the following day, during which both groups sustained minor injuries (coded separately).

Police intervened for peace negotiations, but people also threw stones at them.
Around 22 February 2023 (week of), students from Tambul Secondary protested in Mount Hagen (Western Highlands) demanding the reinstatement of the school principal.

Around 22 February 2023 (week of), hired gunmen kidnapped and held 7 people hostage at a village near Wabag Town, Enga (Coded to Wabag). Police and a unit of the military forces conducted an operation which successfully freed the seven hostages, comprising four young girls, two men and an elderly woman, and arrested the kidnappers. The kidnappers had demanded the release of a warlord from Enga, who together with six other men was arrested earlier that week by Wabag police following the murder of nine people in Ambum valley earlier this year.

On 23 February 2023, gang members kidnapped and held hostage 11 children from the Kamanwan tribe in Kaiap (Enga). Wabag police intercepted the kidnappers and were able to free the children who were unharmed. The kidnappers had demanded the release of seven men who were arrested earlier that week by Wabag police following the murder of nine people in Ambum valley earlier this year.

On 25 February 2023, Tari and Sepik groups clashed at Metro Bridge (coded to Minj, Jiwaka) resulting in 1 death. The motive of the clash is unclear. On 16 March 2023, police arrested the murder suspect in Madang province.

On 22 March 2023, residents from the Kilu (aka Kulingi) community protested and submitted a petition to police representatives in Gabuna ward (West New Britain) demanding that the police arrest those involved in an attempted robbery at Kulingi over the weekend, which resulted in the death of a woman.

On 26 March 2023, a peace and reconciliation ceremony was held between the Finschhafen people living and working on the alluvial mining lease and Wau Waria MP at Mrs Booth ward (Bulolo). On 14 April 2023, protesters from the Akali Tange Association demonstrated at a gold mine in Porgera (Enga), calling for a dialogue with a global mining company over its alleged failure to accept responsibility for ongoing land and water contamination at its gold mine which has displaced locals, and its contribution to ongoing violence, including sexual violence against women. This demonstration coincided with other protests worldwide against the company in anticipation of its Annual General Meeting on 2 May 2023.

On 15 April 2023, unidentified armed assailants attacked a public transport truck causing injuries to 15 people, including Gelegele villagers enroute to Gelegele from Kokopo (coded to Gunanur, East New Britain). Police have arrested a suspect linked to the attack on the public transport truck. Although the identity of the suspect is unknown, Gelegele men blamed the attack on villagers from the Gunanur 2 plantation and retaliated on 15 April 2023 (coded separately).

Around 15 April 2023 (month of), an unidentified group killed two men and a woman in Tambari village (East Sepik). The two men were beheaded and the woman was raped, beaten and slashed with a bush knife before her death. The group also torched 48 homes.

Around 21 April 2023 (as reported), Porgera Secondary School students marched through Paiam Town (Enga), calling for the school's principal to resign because their right to education had been denied due to poor management and leadership, citing a failure to retain teachers, misuse of the school fee subsidy, and deteriorating infrastructure.

On 22 April 2023, the Akols and Komban groups agreed to peace at the Wabag police station in Wabag (Enga). The peace agreement was made before government officials and security forces. Its terms provided that further negotiations would take place for three weeks before the groups meet again on 18 May 2023 to finalize peace resolutions and recommendations. Conflict between the two groups has occurred for more than 10 months involving high powered weapons, resulting in killings, the torching of villages and disruption of government services.

On 24 April 2023, armed men from Nomali and Aiyala clans clashed, leading to the killing of two people and several homes torched in Porgera (Enga). The outbreak was allegedly caused by unmet peace agreement commitments and following the withdrawal of the PNG Defense Forces on 23 April 2023.

The curfew in West New Britain began on 26 April 2023 from 8 pm to 5 am and will continue every day until further notice.

On 3 May 2023, the Pakani and Palge clan groups of the Kombolga tribe agreed to peace at Kenebo (alias Kenembo) in Klenembo ward (Western Highlands). The peace agreement was made before the Western Highlands provincial peace mediation team and police. As part of the peace agreement, Pakani clan gave 97 pigs, three cows, two cassowaries and K94,000 as compensation to the Paige clan for the death of a Paige clan member who was killed in an election-related attack at Kenebo Three polling booth.

On 6 May 2023, relatives of an Engan man carried out a retaliatory attack against Goilala people selling firewood at Stage 2 Gerehu Sports Centre in Port Moresby (National Capital District), killing one Goilala man. The Engans attacked following the alleged robbing and wounding of their relative while he was walking towards the Stage 2 Gerehu Sports Centre. Police are investigating what caused the death of the man from Goilala and the wounding of the man from Enga.

On 12 May 2023, the Foreign Affairs Minister announced that he would stand aside and that the Prime Minister would assume this ministerial role.

On 16 May 2023, supporters of two candidates for the Mul Baiyer Open electorate fought outside the Mount Hagen National Court House in Mount Hagen city (Western Highlands), where a trial regarding a petition made in respect of the 2022 general election was being held. Police were able to quickly stop the fight.

On 16 May 2023, Moge Nambka Tribal armed men, who were fellow tribesman of a murdered man, burnt down five small shops in Mount Hagen (Western Highlands). The shops were burnt down in retaliation over the killing of a prominent leader of the Moge Nambka tribe in Hagen village on 14 May 2023. The man was killed in a fight between the Kopis and Moge Nambka groups (coded separately).

As part of the agreement, the Finschhafen Kandes and Mumeng Kapin took part in an exchange of store food, garden food, nine pigs, and K50,000 to each other. The two groups have been fighting since 26 March 2022, resulting in the loss of lives, destruction to properties, and the displacement of hundreds of families.

On 22 May 2023, hundreds of students from Mount Hagen Technical College and Mount Hagen town residents protested around Mount Hagen (Western Highlands) demanding the Government of Papua New Guinea not to sign the Defence Cooperation Agreement with the United States of America until and unless all Papua New Guinean citizens are fully aware of what is entailed in the Agreement. Police stopped the protest and turned the students back to their school. The Agreement was signed on 22 May 2023 in Port Moresby.

On 22 May 2023, the Papua New Guinea Defense Minister signed a defense cooperation agreement with the United States Secretary of State. Event coded at Port Moresby. According to the United States State Department, the defense agreement will enhance security cooperation and improve the capacity of the Papua New Guinea Defense Force. US$45 million will be provided to Papua New Guinea in new programming and a further US$10 million to prevent conflict and promote stability in Papua New Guinea. The full terms of the agreement will be disclosed once it has entered into legal force under United States law. The agreement triggered nationwide protests led by university students in Papua New Guinea (coded separately).

source: Pacific News Service; Post Courier; RNZ; Solidarity (Australia)
notes: On 22 May 2023, students from the University of Papua New Guinea held a demonstration at their Waigani campus in Port Moresby (National Capital District) to protest the 15-year Papua New Guinea-United States defense cooperation agreement, which was signed before its terms were disclosed to the public. At night, the protest spilled out from the campus onto the streets, stopping traffic. The event was part of a nation-wide protest led by students; the first since 2016 when student-led demonstrations against government corruption resulted in police killing four protesters.

On 22 May 2023, students from Kokopo Business College marched peacefully from their Kenabot campus to the Kokopo-Vunamami Local Level Government Office in Kokopo (East New Britain) to protest the signing of the Defence Cooperation Agreement between Papua New Guinea and the United States of America that occurred that day in Port Moresby. The students expressed their concerns to the Governor of East New Britain at the Office in the presence of provincial leaders and provincial police.

On 22 May 2023, students from the University of Goroka staged a peaceful protest in Goroka Urban (Eastern Highlands) against the signing of the Defence Cooperation Agreement between Papua New Guinea and the United States of America that occurred that day in Port Moresby. The students sought permission from the police to protest march into Goroka town. While waiting for the police response to their request, some students proceeded in a peaceful march out of the University campus and halfway towards Goroka town where police stopped them and turned them back. The students cooperated with police.

On 22 May 2023, hundreds of students from Divine Word University, Nabasa residents, and Gavstoa settlers protested around the University campus in Madang (Madang) against the signing of the Defence Cooperation Agreement between Papua New Guinea and the United States of America that occurred that day in Port Moresby. The protest was led by the Student Representative Council and regional student leaders representing the four regions of Papua New Guinea.

source: Loop News Papua New Guinea; Pacific News Service; PNG Haus Bung
notes: On 22 May 2023, students from the University of Technology held a sit-in demonstration at their Taraka campus in Lae (Morobe) to protest the Papua New Guinea-United States defense cooperation agreement. While no violence occurred during the sit-in protest, some opportunists allegedly prevented access to the campus by blocking nearby roads and bus stops. The event was part of a nation-wide protest led by students.

On 23 May 2023, hundreds of students and people marched through the streets of Mount Hagen (Western Highlands) to protest the 15-year Papua New Guinea-United States defense cooperation agreement, which was signed before its terms were disclosed to the public. Students from Mt Hagen Secondary School attempted to join the protest on the streets but were stopped by police, and instead protested within their school. The event was part of a nation-wide protest led by students; the first since 2016 when student-led demonstrations against government corruption resulted in police killing four protesters.

On 23 May 2023, more than 3,000 students from the Papua New Guinea University of Technology and the National Polytechnic Institute of Papua New Guinea staged a protest and signed a petition within their campus in Lae (Morobe) calling for the Government of Papua New Guinea not to sign the Defence Cooperation Agreement between Papua New Guinea and the United States of America as citizens were not made aware of what the Agreement entailed. The Governor of Morobe was present to receive the students' petition. The Defence Cooperation Agreement was signed on 22 May 2023 in Port Moresby.

On 6 June 2023, a handful of Papua New Guinea Trade Union Congress members protested peacefully outside the National Parliament House in Port Moresby (National Capital District) during a Parliament session, calling for the removal of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (who is also a Moresby South MP) following his derogatory comment regarding the travel of Morobe Governor's daughter to King Charles's coronation in England. On 6 June 2023, taxi drivers enacted a strike and gathered at the Lae Rugby League oval in Lae (Morobe) calling on the authorities to guarantee their safety after a taxi driver was attacked by two youths he was dropping off on 2 June 2023.

Property destruction: On 7 June 2023, more than 40 armed men allegedly looted and destroyed classrooms and teacher's houses at Walagu Primary School in Walagu village in Komo-Magarima district (coded to Margarima city, Hela). The teaching staff and their families fled into the jungles of Walagu.

Property destruction: On 7 June 2023, more than 40 armed men allegedly looted and destroyed classrooms and teacher's houses at Walagu Primary School at Walagu village in Waragu ward (Southern Highlands). The teaching staff and their families fled into the jungles of Walagu.

Around 7 June 2023 (week of), the Peraka and Kaika tribes signed a peace agreement at Alkina subdistrict station in Tambul-Nebilyer (coded to Alkena 1, Western Highlands), ending 35 years of tribal fighting. The signing was witnessed by the Provincial Police Commander and other prominent community leaders.

notes: On 7 June 2023, more than 40 armed men kidnapped 17 primary school girls from their homes at Walagu village in Waragu ward (Southern Highlands), sexually assaulted the girls and demanded a ransom for their return. In addition, the men entered Walaku Primary School with homemade guns and bush knives, where they looted and destroyed classrooms and teachers' homes. Eyewitnesses claimed that the incident was not caused by tribal or ethnic clashes. The perpetrators have demanded K40,000 and 10 pigs for the release of the girls, and are believed to have been involved in the kidnapping of a New Zealand researcher and his assistants on 19 February 2023 (coded separately). On 12 July 2023, police arrested one of the armed men in Hela.

On 7 June 2023, taxi drivers protested outside Ignatius Kilage Stadium in Lae (Morobe), calling for traffic police to identify dangerous locations and allocate designated areas for taxis to stop or turn, following an attack on an elderly taxi driver who was stabbed multiple times on 5 June 2023.

On 8 June 2023, the Yandapu and Palinu tribes clashed in the Tsak Valley area in the Wapenamanda District (Coded to Wapenamanda Urban, Enga) resulting in the death of a Yandapu man. Fighting between these two groups had been going on for almost a year, resulting in around 14 men killed on both sides.

On 8 June 2023, the Sikin tribe ambushed and killed a Itiokon man at the Lai River Bridge Crossing (Enga). Fighting between these two groups started recently, resulting in multiple deaths including a ward member.

notes: On 8 June 2023, Baining villagers destroyed a vehicle and burnt down a wooden bridge at lower Toriu in Mandrambit (East New Britain). The villagers had suspected that the vehicle, which had stopped to fix a tire, was trying to kidnap a child crying by the roadside. They then mobilized and chased the passengers away, stealing K24,000 from the vehicle before destroying it and burning the bridge. The group later burnt down the properties of Mandrambit Primary School in the same ward, destroying classrooms, school administration buildings, and two teachers' houses. Teachers and students fled when the Bainings villagers entered the school ground.

On 12 June 2023, hundreds of supporters of the former Prime Minister, who is also the current MP for Ialibu-Pangia, rallied outside Boroko Police Station and Police Headquarters in Port Moresby (National Capital District), calling for the former Prime Minister to be treated with respect. The former Prime Minister has been charged with three counts of giving false evidence under oath before a commission of inquiry.

The Tongai Mamalka tribe gave K15,000, 11 pigs, and a cow to the MP as compensation for a fight during the 2022 National General Elections, resulting in the MP's properties being burnt down. The protestors appealed to both the provincial and national government to have the highway repaired as deteriorated sections of the highway caused drivers to slow down making them vulnerable to criminal attacks.

Security measures: On 20 June 2023, the Oro Provincial Executive Council in Popondetta Urban (Oro) announced the implementation of a province-wide curfew by police to curb escalating law and order issues. Over the past two months, there has been a surge in fatal fights and assault cases, leading to a one-week shutdown of a town. The police are currently in pursuit of 24 suspects. The curfew in Oro Province began on 23 June 2023 from 10 pm to 5 am for 30 days.

Security measures: Around 21 June 2023 (week of), the Enga Provincial Executive Council in Wapenamanda Urban (Enga) declared Wapenamanda a fighting zone after 10 people were killed following a tribal fight between Mupapalu and Nenei clans of Itiokon tribe on 12 June 2023 (coded separately). The declaration gave both police and defense personnel the power to carry out raids and arrests in Wapenamanda without an official complaint or warrant.

The police would arrest anyone occupying the land under the provisions of the Intergroup Fumigation Act.

The Yangolam and Komain clans will pay K500,000 and 100 pigs to Akols in mid-December 2023 as decided by the joint village court for this agreement. Fighting began following polling for the General Election in 2022, when an Akol councilor was killed near Komban territory, leading to the Akols retaliating against the Kombans. The fighting resulted in many people killed and displaced, and properties destroyed. The Akols and Komban groups first agreed to peace on 22 April, 2023 (coded separately).

On 22 June 2023, leaders of the Herep 1 and Herep 2 signed a peace agreement in Mendi town (Southern Highlands) to reconcile after 10 years of fighting. The peace agreement was negotiated by the Nipa-Kutubu MP. The signing was witnessed by the Provincial Police Commander, Provincial Magistrate, and local community leaders.

There are conflicting reports with regards to the date of the event (one report mentions that the event occurred around 23 June, while another one mentions that it occurred in August). On 10 December 2023, the Yawar and Bom people agreed to peace near Bom (Madang).

On 24 June 2023, the Melye and Nenga tribes agreed to make peace in a compensation ceremony at Kunt Primary School in Mul-Baiyer district (coded to Wangumali, Southern Highlands). The Melye tribe paid the Nenga tribe more than K100,000 in cash and around 100 animals including a python and a horse as compensation for the death of a Nenga man in 2022. The ceremony was witnessed by the Mul-Baiyer MP (who was also from Melye tribe), community leaders, and more than 3,000 people.

source: Loop News Papua New Guinea; Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 3 July 2023, youths from Wanigela Settlement, along with the relatives and community members of a man killed by security guards, rioted in the Koki suburb of Port Moresby (National Capital District). The riot was sparked by the killing of a robber in Koki by security guards. All commercial activities in the affected area were suspended indefinitely. On 4 July 2023, National Capital District police arrested 56 people suspected of participating in the riot. Police are still assessing the extent of the damage and injuries caused by the riot.

notes: Around 6 July 2023 (as reported), a group of Moim and Tambari men killed villagers, torched homes, and destroyed properties in Angoram district (coded to Angoram Urban, East Sepik). According to the Kambaramba village chairman, the attack was in retaliation after a Moim village leader lured Kindaguno and Kol Ples villagers to Angoram police station to make peace over the killing of a former Moim councilor, but the Moim village leader did not attend the peace meeting. The former Moim councilor was killed in 2018 because he had familial ties to Kambaramba village, and some Tambari and Moim villagers oppose those with familial ties to neighboring villages from contesting council elections and have formed groups to kill them and their supporters. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 July 2023, service providers from across Madang province protested outside the Provincial Treasury Office in Madang (Madang), demanding clarification on outstanding payments owed to them for services rendered to the provincial administration. The protesters allege that some payments have been delayed for at least 15 months, and the amounts owed range from K100,000 to more than K1,000,000. Police were called to pacify the protesters, who agreed to meet with Madang province's financial manager, administrator and governor on 11 July 2023.

On 8 July 2023, a group of 20 drunken Engans fought with locals from Baiyer at Baiyer River (coded to Baiyer, Western Highlands), resulting in three men having their arms cut off and seven others sustained knife wounds. The Engans had traveled to Baiyer River for a compensation ceremony but they got drunk and fought with the locals before the ceremony started. Police are investigating the incident.

Displacement: On 11 July 2023, around 600 people were evicted by police from Konebada, Portion 26, Lot 81 in Port Moresby (National Capital District) following a 2010 court order where a local company, Decision 2000 Ltd, obtained the land title. The residents are second and third-generation family members of former National Housing Corporation employees from 1960 to 1970, who were purportedly allowed to reside on the land pending government repatriation. The residents who did not heed the eviction order were forced to vacate the land when a bulldozer and excavator, escorted by police, demolished trees, fences, market stalls and homes. They are now living in makeshift tents by the roadside in Konebada.

On 25 July 2023, the Kahasa and Kesua clans clashed in Serembeng village (Morobe) after a land mediation between the two clans. A man was killed in the clash and another hospitalized. Relatives of the deceased retaliated by torching 20 houses in the village (coded separately). On 28 July 2023, police arrested 36 suspects who were involved in the clash.

notes: Around 16 August 2023 (week of), the Minimbi Kimbo and Kopon Kopi tribes made peace in the Tigi area of Baiyer River (coded to Tigi.1 ward, Western Highlands) over the death of a girl from the Kopon Kopi tribe earlier in the year. The girl was killed after jumping out of a speeding vehicle owned by a Minimbi Kimbo man. The Kopon Kopi tribe then shot and injured a Minimbi Kimbo man in retaliation. During the peace ceremony, the Minimbi Kimbo tribe paid compensation to the Kopon Kopi tribe for the death of the girl while the Kopon Kopi tribe paid 'bel kol' to the Minimbi tribe for the man shot in retaliation, promising to pay compensation if he dies. The ceremony was witnessed by the Western Highlands provincial police commander and the provincial peace team.

On 11 September 2023, five clans from Kandep district agreed to a ceasefire at Titip Primary School, Titip ward (Enga). The five clans agreed to lay down their arms and petitioned the Member for Kandep to apprehend the perpetrators of the 24 incurred deaths. Twenty-four clansmen who fled the violence had drowned while trying to escape the previous conflict by crossing the Lai River. The MP for Kandep promised to have the perpetrators arrested and settle the aggrieved family members of the 24 deceased. The ceasefire agreement was initiated by the MP for Kandep and witnessed by district administration staff, peace officers, security officers, local leaders, and more than 5,000 people.

A restraining order will be served to both factions following the ceasefire agreement.

notes: On 19 September 2023, the Korofeigu tribe signed a peace agreement with the Nagamiufa and Kama tribes near Goroka Urban (Eastern Highlands). The agreement signified the end of conflict among the tribes that followed the killing of a Korofeigu man by Nagamiufa tribesmen on 17 September 2022 (coded separately). On 19 September 2022, Korofeigu tribesmen raided Nagamiufa village in retaliation, severely injuring three villagers and torching numerous homes, causing 418 women and children to became homeless (coded separately). The signing of the peace agreement was witnessed by the Eastern Highlands Governor, the Provincial Administrator, District Development Authority CEO, Provincial Police Commander, members of the provincial peace committee, and church leaders.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)

This followed a riot on 18 September 2023 where students torched 4 school vehicles and damaged school property (coded separately). The students demanded the Minister of Higher Education, Research, Science, and Technology receive their petition in person within 48 hours. The issues raised in the petition include the accreditation of the Bachelor in Renewable Energy and Climate Change program, more tutors for the program, and the sacking of the university's senior management team over alleged malpractice within the university administration. The East New Britain Governor, Acting Provincial Administrator, Provincial Police Commander, and members of the provincial executive council were present to hear the student's demands.

On 21 September 2023, six tribes in the Guari local level government area reconciled in a peace ceremony at Kamulai Mission Station, Kamulai (Central) to end years of conflict among themselves. The peace and reconciliation program was initiated by the Governor of Central and Member for Goilala. It was witnessed by the Governor and Member, ward and community leaders, and local villagers.

On 21 September 2023, one men died in a tribal revenge killing involving two unidentified tribes or clans in Hulia LLG, Komo-Magarima district, Hela (coded at Hol'la). The killing led to a clash between the Walapani and Poroli clans at Piangonda market (coded separately).

On 21 September 2023, students from Papua New Guinea University of Natural Resources and Environment torched 2 school vehicles on their campus in Vudal (East New Britain) as a result of continuing internal issues between the student body and school management that have not been addressed since 2021. On 18 September 2023, the rioters torched 4 school vehicles and damaged school property (coded separately). On 23 September 2023, Walapani and Poroli clans clashed at Piangonda market (coded to Piangoga 1, Hela) resulting in the death of two men. The fight erupted after a man was killed on 21 September 2023 in a reprisal killing. Security forces have been deployed in the area to monitor the conflict.

Around 24 September 2023, two tribes clashed in Tebi LLG, Tabi-Pori, Hela (coded to Kela 1) leading to the death of two men. The bodies were found on 24 September at Kela 1 council ward. State forces were deployed to monitor the tribal fighting in the area.

On 5 October 2023 (as reported), police released 31 students. On 10 October 2023 (as reported), 15 students remain detained at the Kokopo police holding cell.

On 30 September 2023, villagers blocked the Magi Highway with felled trees and debris at Gaire (Central), demonstrating the death of man and woman who were allegedly run over by an intoxicated police officer in a vehicle that day. The villagers demanded accountability from the police officer and sought assistance from the Central Governor and Hiri Koiari MP to cover funeral expenses for the deceased individuals. On 1 October 2023, the villagers removed the roadblock after being addressed by the Central provincial police commander. Police are investigating. On 9 October 2023, police arrested the police officer and charged him with two counts of reckless driving causing the death of a couple.

On 17 November 2023, a peace agreement was signed between two families of Masuko at Masuko, Yonggomugl (Sina Sina-Yonggomugl, Chimbu), ending a sorcery-related conflict that began in 2019 following the sudden death of a community member. The dispute had escalated into a fight that involved members of the wider community, causing property damage and bush knife injuries. The ceremony, led by local businessman William Kau, church pastors, and community elders, formalized reconciliation and marked the community's commitment to move past accusations, focus on development, and restore peace.

Around 11 December 2023 (between 10 December - 12 December), relatives of a deceased man torched 5 houses and killed 3 pigs at Herebo (Southern Highlands) in retaliation of his death. The relatives accused Herebo villagers of using sorcery to kill the man. The villagers agreed to pay compensation for his death on 10 December 2023. However, they failed to honor their commitment triggering the retaliation by the relatives.

On 12 December 2023, the Yauna and Punano tribe clashed in Isontenu, Akuitenu (Eastern Highlands) resulting in 6 deaths, homes and structures on both sides torched, and many people displaced. The Yauna tribe torched 10 houses of the Punano tribe. This followed a fight between the two groups around 19 October 2023 over land ownership issues. Police are investigating.

Around 15 December 2023 (month of), two months of fighting between the Maimai clan (coded as Maimai tribe) and the Pokale clan (coded as Pokale tribe) in Pilikambi Rural LLG (coded to Kanak, Enga) resulted in 10 deaths and thousands of kina worth of properties lost. The fight began when members of the Maimai clan attacked and killed a Pokale man in November 2023 (coded separately).

On 15 December 2023, a group of armed youths from Nunzung attacked Sangneng villagers and torched several houses in Sangneng village, Zaningu (Morobe) resulting in some villagers wounded and many displaced. This followed a fight on 28 November 2023 between Kip and Kalasa villagers that spread to involve others in the area.

notes: On 10 January 2024, hundreds of National Capital District police officers, correctional officers, armed forces, and other government workers abandoned their posts and marched towards Parliament in Port Moresby (National Capital District), demonstrating the deduction of 300 Kina from their monthly salaries. The government stated that the deduction was the result of a technical error in the payroll process, and not due to a new tax which the demonstrators had initially alleged. A video depicting the security services marching went viral, and numerous local police also abandoned their posts, which resulted in rioting, looting and property damage in Port Moresby hours after the march (coded separately). Some demonstrators overran the gate of the parliament building and torched a car outside the compound.

notes: On 10 January 2024, riots took hold in parts of Lae (Lae) resulting in 5 deaths (international media reported 7 deaths), 8 injuries, and numerous shops looted. In response, Lae police and private security forces shot and killed 4 suspected looters, abruptly ending the riot. However, the father of a male university student killed during the riot alleges his son's death was caused by a police officer's misfired warning shot into a crowd of bystanders. According to the provincial administrator, the rioters' motives were to imitate what they observed from viral footage taken from Port Moresby earlier that day, namely, the complete collapse of law and order as a consequence of a total abdication of responsibility by police, prison guards and armed forces in Port Moresby (coded separately).

Around 11 January 2024 (as reported), rioting and looting occurred in Bulolo (unclear if it occurred in Bulolo district or town), following similar events in the capital. The rioting has spread out to other part of the country, including in Lae, Kokopo, Goroka, Madang and Kavienga (coded separately).

Security measures: On 11 January 2024, Papua New Guinea Prime Minister announced a State of Emergency for a period of 14 days in Port Moresby (National Capital District). The Prime Minister stated that it was necessary to allow for a select committee to investigate whether the riots on 10 January were instigated by political forces. The Prime Minister also suspended the Chief of Police, as well as the respective departmental secretaries of Treasury and Finance.

They stole the guards' uniforms and disguised themselves as guards, but were intercepted by NARI security officers. After their failed attempt to break into the canteen, they entered the house of a health worker, who is also a government worker, and beat and stabbed 3 of the health worker's relatives. Their house was also looted. A church pastor was also injured by the assailants.

On 14 February 2024, Pindiu villages agreed to peace in a peace ceremony at Gagidu town, Gagidu (Morobe) ending 8 years of conflict between them that resulted in 5 deaths and 84 houses torched. According to the Morobe police commander, the conflict followed differences in landownership. The peace ceremony was witness by representatives from the Pindiu villages and police.

The tribal leaders agreed to an unconditional ceasefire of three months to allow for the PNG government to proceed with conflict resolution and humanitarian relief strategies in the area. The ceasefire agreement was witnessed by the Police Commissioner, Enga Provincial Administrator, and tribal leaders from both sides after 6 days of negotiations. The three years of conflict between the Yopo and Palinu tribes, and their allies, resulted in thousands killed, millions of kina worth of properties destroyed, and the displacement of thousands of men, women, and children.

notes: On 3 May 2024, more than 400 small scale and alluvial miners holding placards and banners staged a peaceful protest at Wau Oval, Wau Urban (Morobe) against the proposed National Gold Corporation Bill 2022. The miners argued that the Bill would destroy the alluvial mining sector as they would be forced to sell to one buyer only at the set rate. The protest was led by the President of the Morobe Goldfield Small Scale Miners Association Incorporation. The President presented a petition containing over 400 signatures from lease holders opposing the Bill to the Member for Wau-Waria. The protestors appealed to the Member to present their petition in Parliament during the May sitting.

assoc_actor_1: Miamboru Communal Group (Papua New Guinea); Vigilante Group (Papua New Guinea)

The villagers accused the two men of practicing sorcery on another villager who had recently died. The rioters then torched houses and destroyed properties in the village in retaliation. Police have identified 15 suspects who are still at large.

On 7 May 2024, the Krange-Kalpa clan (coded as Krange-Kalpa tribe) and the Kimi-Komunka clan (coded as Kimi-Komunka tribe) agreed to peace in a peace ceremony at Gulka village, Kimil No. 2 ward (Jiwaka) ending 8 months of conflict between them following the killing of a Kimi-Komunka man by suspected members of the Krange-Kalpa clan in September 2023 (coded separately). The Krange-Kalpa clan presented K90,500, 89 pigs, four cows, six goats, and a cuscus to the Kimi-Komunka clan to signify the restoration of peace and normalcy. The North Waghi peace mediation team and Western Highlands Dei district leaders brokered the peace agreement between the two factions. The ceremony was witnessed by local police, correctional officers, and the local community.

Property destruction: Around 11 May 2024 (weekend of), about 40 armed men looted and torched houses and killed livestock at Iliye village (coded at Samakopa ward, assuming that it occurred within Bamu Rural LLG), Western, after the villagers refused to hand over a demand letter to a logging company nearby. Hundreds of families fled into the jungle for safety. These men are believed to have been involved in the kidnapping of a New Zealand researcher and his assistants on 19 February 2023 (coded separately), the sexual assault of 17 primary school girls on 7 June 2023 (code separately), and the kidnapping of an Australian pilot and 2 locals on 26 February 2024 (coded separately).

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)

notes: On 22 June 2024, 4 local level governments (LLG) of Kabwum district conducted a 2-day peace and reconciliation ceremony with district officers and public servants at Kabwum Station (Morobe), ending tensions following the 2022 general election violence, during which election materials and ballot papers were burned and several fights occurred (coded separately). Representatives from Selepet, Yus, Komba, and Deyamous LLG apologized to the Kabwum public servants and the Morobe Provincial Government. Locals showed their support by turning up with their faces painted in black ash, demonstrating sympathy and unity. The ceremony was witnessed by government officials, provincial services improvement programs coordinator, police officers, and LLG representatives.

source: Loop News Papua New Guinea; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 23 June 2024, 4 local level governments of Kabwum district conducted a 2-day peace and reconciliation ceremony with district officers and public servants at Kabwum Station (Morobe), ending tensions following the 2022 general election violence, during which election materials and ballot papers were burned and several fights occurred (coded separately). Following a church service, Selepet LLG reconciled with public servants and the acting district administrator and invited them to return to the district office. Locals showed their support by turning up with their faces painted in black ash, demonstrating sympathy and unity. The ceremony was witnessed by government officials, provincial services improvement programs coordinator, police officers, and LLG representatives.

On 24 June 2024, demonstrators staged a protest at Menyamya Station (Morobe) to oppose and call for repealing the provincial government's decision that gives ward councilors exclusive voting rights to elect local level government presidents.

On 28 June 2024, the Galeboka sub-clan (coded as Galeboka tribe) and Nara clan (coded as Nara tribe) agreed to peace at Tabibuga station, Tabibuga (Jiwaka) ending 2 years of conflict between them. The conflict followed the killing of a Galeboka clan leader during the 2022 National General Elections (coded separately). The two groups exchanged soft drinks as sign of peace. The peace ceremony was witnessed by the Jiwaka Provincial Police Commander Albert, Jiwaka Provincial Government executives, and more than a thousand people from Upper, Middle and Lower Jimi. Representatives from donor partners were also present at the ceremony.

source: AFP; Guardian; Post Courier; Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary; The National (Papua New Guinea); TVWAN
notes: On 17 July 2024, more than 30 I Don't Care (IDC) gang members attacked locals in Agrumara village (East Sepik), resulting in at least 3 killings, including an elderly man and a 5-year-old boy and the burning of houses. The motive for the attack was a land dispute. The attack occurred in three villages in Angoram: Agrumara (17 July), Tamara (between 16 - 18 July) (coded separately), and Tambari (18 July) (coded separately). Survivors of the attack said that 63 people were killed, while authorities said the number of fatalities in the attack on the three villages may rise to more than 50. The prime suspect in the massacre surrendered to the police. He was caught on camera directing the gang members to dismember a diseased man's corpse. Eight suspects are in police custody.

The riot stemmed from the burning of a former Maprik MP brother's trucks the previous day (coded separately), which led to retaliatory attacks by people believed to be from his brother's village. Local police tried to intervene but retreated after being attacked with wire catapults. Villagers came to the police's aid, who arrested 189 suspected individuals responsible for the attack. The public burned a Pangu office, a shop and vehicles owned by the former MP.

A bishop said that although no weapons were surrendered at the peace ceremony, both sides were told to lay down their arms. The ceremony was attended by a chief magistrate, police, district administrator, councilors, and community leaders.

The people of Visikum refused to compensate the people of Gatikum, hence, the incident remained unresolved.

The two victims and three men are suspected to be from the same tribe in Wabag (Enga), however the police are still investigating to establish what happened and why it happened.

On 16 September 2024, Mount Kodu landowners from Naoro village blocked the Kokoda Track in protest to the national government at Naoro village (coded at Kokoda Urban, Sohe, Oro) that led to a group Australian Trekkers having to turn back around. The landowners protested against the national government for an alleged non-payment of a K40 million commitment that was agreed upon in 2013, for the locals to forgo the Mt Kodu gold mine project and preserve the track as a historical site. The track is closed for an indefinite period.

On 17 September 2024, an elderly man's house was burnt down after he was accused of practicing sorcery by a group of youths from Baimuru, at Ashe, Evore waterfront, Kerema Town (Gulf). The youths were under the influence when they accused the elderly of practicing sorcery that led to one of the accusers chopping off the hands of another youth also under the influence of alcohol; the victim's relative then retaliated by setting fire to the elderly man's house.

On 17 September 2024, students from Balob Teachers College clashed with Hunta settlers at Balob Teachers College (Lae, Morobe), resulting in four injured students, valuables and properties lost. The incident occurred after students were robbed by youths from the nearby Hunta settlement, the students then mobilized to retaliate against the settlers leading to the fight.

Metropolitan Commander met up with the settlers the next day confirming that the NCD Police had no knowledge of an eviction exercise.

notes: On 19 September 2024, five people in an ambulance were ambushed and held hostage for several hours by armed men from Sakar clan at Yonge village in Lagaip (coded to Aiyak (Aiyaka), Lagaip-Porgera, Enga). The driver was thrown out of the vehicle as the men got in the ambulance and drove away with the five people; three of which were women, two of them were pregnant. The driver was later rescued by the police and PNG defense force and the five hostages we released unharmed. The reason for the incident was because, according to the armed men, the ambulance did not help the Sakar clansmen when they needed help.

The police arrested the four suspects the next day, then on 2 October arrested 13 people accused of being involved in the torture of the four juveniles. The 13 people were later released on 11 October and the four suspect on 18 October, which led to a fight on 2 November 2024 (coded separately).

Security measures: On 23 September 2024, the Governor-General declared an official National Emergency in the districts of Porgera-Paiela (coded to Porgera), Kompiam Ambum (coded separately to Londor), and Wapenamanda (coded separately to Anji) in Enga Province following the incident that transpired at Porgera (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) between the Sakar and Piande clans (coded separately), in order to stop unprecedented violence and tribal fight in the province. On 15 September, police declared Porgera Station a non-access area for all non-residents adding that a curfew is in effect between 6pm and 8am, as well as, a ban on the sale of liquor throughout the valley (coded separately). The Police Commissioner said the focus of the security forces is entirely on protecting lives and critical infrastructure.

On 23 September 2024, displaced mothers, children, and men, who were the victims of the incident at Porgera held a peaceful protest march at Porgera station (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) to call for long-term peace. The protesters painted their bodies in mud and charcoal to show their sorrow, and held placards as they marched into the Porgera station to meet the Police Minister, Governor for Enga Province, and Police Commissioner. The Police Commissioner addressed people announcing that the state of emergency controller will be releasing the operational orders for PNG Defence Force and Police operations.

Security measures: On 23 September 2024, the Governor-General declared an official National Emergency in the districts of Kompiam Ambum (coded to Londor), Porgera-Paiela (coded separately to Porgera) and Wapenamanda (coded separately to Anji) in Enga Province following the incident that transpired at Porgera (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) between the Sakar and Piande clans (coded separately), in order to stop unprecedented violence and tribal fight in the province. On 15 September, police declared Porgera Station a non-access area for all non-residents adding that a curfew is in effect between 6pm and 8am, as well as, a ban on the sale of liquor throughout the valley (coded separately). The Police Commissioner said the focus of the security forces is entirely on protecting lives and critical infrastructure.

Security measures: On 23 September 2024, the Governor-General declared an official National Emergency in the districts of Wapenamanda (coded to Anji), Porgera-Paiela (coded separately to Porgera), and Kompiam Ambum (coded separately to Londor), and in Enga Province following the incident that transpired at Porgera (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) between the Sakar and Piande clans (coded separately), in order to stop unprecedented violence and tribal fight in the province. On 15 September, police declared Porgera Station a non-access area for all non-residents adding that a curfew is in effect between 6pm and 8am, as well as, a ban on the sale of liquor throughout the valley (coded separately). The Police Commissioner said the focus of the security forces is entirely on protecting lives and critical infrastructure.

On 24 September 2024, a 15-seater public motor vehicle transport carrying 14 passengers travelling between Porgera and Wabag was pounded with bush knives and axes by a group of 10 armed men (likely from Laiagam based on the location of the event) at Ipai village (Lagaip Rural LLG, Lagaip-Porgera, Enga). It was alleged that 10 armed men in a land cruiser attempted to block the road and stop the PMV bus in order to check for their enemies inside but weren't able to when the PMV driver continued driving past the land cruiser, causing the armed men to pound on the vehicle with bush knives and axes in an attempt to stop it. The bus driver and passengers made it through without any injuries but there was extensive damage to the vehicle. The incident was described as part of a tribal fight (likely the recent tribal fight at Porgera based on the location of the event).

On 24 September 2024, landowners and residents of Epo to Kerema town turned up at the Technical Service Division office at the Kerema Provincial Government office (Kerema Town, Gulf) to protest overdue payments of cash crop that was damaged during the 15 months of a road sealing project by Dekenai Construction. The landowners depended on the cash crops for their livelihood. It has been three years since the project and the landowners still await their claim.

Around 25 September 2024 (weekend of), relatives of a deceased youth set up a roadblock to protest at Tohatsi village, Halia ward (North Bougainville, Bougainville) following an incident where the victim was stabbed by his girlfriend's cousin which resulted from a confrontation, after the girlfriend's cousin had found out that the two had spent a night together. The victim's father has appealed to his relatives to remove the road block and to allow justice to take its course.

On 28 September 2024, relatives of a youth from Ward 15 who died after a soccer injury burned down seven homes, a trade store, a bottle shop, and other properties, totaling 70 homes near the Boana government station in Gamiki (Nawae, Morobe) suspecting sorcery as the cause of the youth death. Police had responded to the scene twice but no arrests had been made; meanwhile, efforts are underway to help the victims rebuild their homes with the assistance of community leaders. The victims of sorcery-related violence, perpetrated by relatives of a youth were forced to flee their homes.

On 28 September 2024, Visikum villagers and Gatikum villagers engaged in a four-day fight in North-Wosera LLG (coded at Sarikum, Wosera-Gawi, East Sepik) that has left five fatalities, 300 houses burnt, and many injured, following a drunken brawl between a man from Gatikum village and another from Visikum village who attacked each other in retaliation over another incident involving the Visikum magistrate's son that occurred in mid-September (coded separately). The villages are a kilometer apart and with only one police officer stationed at the North-Wosera Chamber the fight continued for four days, causing nearby health centers to close and schools to be suspended for an indefinite period; the villagers continued to beat traditional drums signaling the people to take up arms and continue to fight. 5 fatalities were split over four events; 2 fatalities were coded for this event.

On 29 September 2024, a member of an armed robbery group was chased by a mob and hacked to death at Tokara suburb, Port Moresby (National Capital District) following an armed robbery incident. After eight armed men robbed a local shop operated by Bangladesh nationals, a security guard was shot dead, and another sustained a bullet wound to his thigh in an attempt to stop the men from escaping. In retaliation, a mob chased down one of the members of the group that was left stranded whilst the other members ran away and hacked the man to death.

On 29 September 2024, Visikum villagers and Gatikum villagers continued to fight in North-Wosera LLG (coded at Sarikum, Wosera-Gawi, East Sepik). This was part of a four-day fight, which started on 28 September and that left five fatalities, 300 houses burnt, and many injured, following a drunken brawl between a man from Gatikum village and another from Visikum village who attacked each other in retaliation over another incident involving the Visikum magistrate's son that occurred in mid-September (coded separately). 5 fatalities were split over four events; 1 fatality was coded for this event.

On 30 September 2024, about 2,000 South Seas Tuna employees staged a peaceful protest over minimum wage and foreign employee issues at Wewak (East Sepik). Employees walked out of work at 7am in the morning and went to the East Sepik's deputy governor's office and the union to raise their concerns. Employees were urged to resume work after receiving assurance that their concerns would be looked into and addressed immediately.
