This was part of a four-day fight, which started on 28 September and that left five fatalities, 300 houses burnt, and many injured, following a drunken brawl between a man from Gatikum village and another from Visikum village who attacked each other in retaliation over another incident involving the Visikum magistrate's son that occurred in mid-September (coded separately). 5 fatalities were split over four events; 1 fatality was coded for this event. Health centers nearby have closed, while schools within the area have been suspended indefinitely, as some students have also taken part in the fight and are injured while teachers who have gone away for holidays have not returned since they heard of the incident.

assoc_actor_1: Highlands Region Communal Group (Papua New Guinea); New Guinea Islands Region Communal Group (Papua New Guinea); Southern Region Communal Group (Papua New Guinea); Students (Papua New Guinea)
assoc_actor_2: Momase Region Communal Group (Papua New Guinea); Students (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 1 October 2024, a fight broke out among the Mamose students, on one side and, Highlands, New Guinea Islands, and Southern region students, on the other side, at the Kokopo Business College (Kokopo, East New Britian), resulting in the expulsion of 21 students. The fight was triggered by an incident dated back to August of this year (coded separately). The fighting on 1 October occurred when the on-campus students prevented the Mamose students from accessing the mess facilities that led to the Mamose students arming themselves with wire catapults and attacking on-campus students. The school administration took precautionary measures to deal with the situation and expelled 7 students from Mamose region, 7 from Highlands region, and 7 from the New Guinea Islands Region.

Around 1 October 2024 (beginning of month), a fight took place between villagers of Lambutina and Basakalo at Sio in Wasu (Tewae-Siassi, Morobe) that resulted in several people injured and 400 displaced, as well as 30 homes burned and extensive property damage. Police presence managed to stop the fight and the Lambutina villagers have agreed to rebuild 30 houses that were burned down at Basakalo village so that peace can be established, while Basakalo villagers are being sheltered at Solo Primary School.

On 1 October 2024, Visikum villagers and Gatikum villagers continued to fight at North-Wosera LLG (coded at Sarikum, Wosera-Gawi, East Sepik). This was part of a four-day fight, which started on 28 September and that left five fatalities, 300 houses burnt, and many injured, following a drunken brawl between a man from Gatikum village and another from Visikum village who attacked each other in retaliation over another incident involving the Visikum magistrate's son that occurred in mid-September (coded separately). 5 fatalities were split over five events; 1 fatality was coded for this event.

actor1: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-)
notes: Movement of forces: On 2 October 2024, Police from the Special Services Division (SSD) from the Southern Mobile Group in Port Moresby arrived at North-Wosera LLG (coded at Sarikum, Wosera-Gawi, East Sepik) to assist the local police task force, following a fight between Gatikum and Visikum villagers with a confirmed fatality of five people, the entire Gatikum village razed, and 100 families homeless (coded separately). The police will start investigations into the crimes committed and make arrests.

assoc_actor_1: Nomu Tribal Group (Papua New Guinea); Christian Group (Papua New Guinea); Government of Papua New Guinea (2019-); Ziwe Tribal Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Agreement: On 5 October 2024, community leaders and ward members of the Nomu, Ziwe, and Amugen tribes in Sialum LLG of the Tewae-Siassi, the Morobe Provincial Government and the church signed a peace agreement at Sialum Local Level Government (coded at Gitua, Tewae-Siassi, Morobe). This put an end to the conflict that started in July last year (2023) and continued to this year (2024), resulting in the closure of 5 schools, 2 health facilities, and government offices in Sialum LLG. The communities are now focused on restoring law and order, bringing normalcy back to the community, and how to improve and settle the displaced people back to the community.

On 10 October 2024, the family of a victim killed by a suspected police officer and other residents of Alotau town marched in protest through the streets of Alotau to bring a petition to the police headquarters at Alotau (Milne Bay). The family requested a thorough and impartial investigation into the killing. The Milne Bay provincial police commander received the petition and handed it over to the visiting Assistant Commissioner of Police (southern end). On 16 September, the victim was at a local tavern when he suspectedly intervened in a confrontation between the police officer and another local when he and the local were shot dead by the police officer with a police-issued riffle (coded separately).

actor2: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-)
assoc_actor_2: Civilians (Papua New Guinea); Labor Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 11 October 2024, armed men believed to be from Kipul tribe of Porgera-Paiela engaged in a shootout with special security forces personnel at Mulitaka (Muritaka, Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) when the group ambushed a New Porgera Mining Limited 30 vehicle convoy travelling from Mt Hagen and were passing through the emergency access route past the Mulitaka disaster area. The armed men blocked off the road and opened fire on convoy and the security force, causing damages to eight vehicles belonging to the special security forces and one that belongs to the mine. They burned mine fuel pump equipment, destroyed two 640 haul trucks, a helipad, and removed planks on the bridge that connects road links to Porgera as they did not want vehicles from the mine accessing the emergency road. The event resulted in 1 fatality (likely a member of the Kipul tribe based on the reporting) and 5 men injured by the security forces.

On 11 October 2024, armed men from the Mulapin tribe ambushed a vehicle carrying passengers from Sakare clan near Tambitanis Health Centre at Sirunki (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga). The vehicle was transporting a body when the ambush occurred, resulting in 1 fatality, and several others sustaining serious injuries. An hour later armed men from Sakare clan retaliated killing a driver and his passenger who were from the Mulapin tribe (coded separately). The violence is related to an attack against an illegal miner from the Mulapin tribe organized by the Sakare clan on 20 March.

On 11 October 2024, two men from Mulapin tribe, driver and his passenger, were killed by men from Sakare clan at Ipai corner near Sirunki (coded to Sirunki, Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) in retaliation after armed men from Mulapin ambushed a vehicle carrying passengers from the Sakare clan resulting in 1 death (coded separately).

On 12 October 2024, the Ukini tribe and Mapowa tribe of Baiyer engaged in a tribal fight at Baiyer (Baiyer Station, Mul-Baiyer, Western Highlands). The fight started after relatives of a women from Ukuni attacked her husband from Mapowa, on the same day, because he had assaulted the woman. One Ukini man was killed in retaliation.

actor1: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-)
notes: Arrest: On 12 October 2024, 62 illegal miners were arrested by the police at the Porgera mine open pit (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) while attempting to steal gold-bearing material. The illegal miners are currently detained at the Porgera Police Station and will undergo processing and face appropriate charges.

On 13 October 2024, a group of relatives of 2 victims burned a civilian's house at Nonga (Rabaul, East New Britain) after the civilian's son was suspected of the murder of the two victims. The police are still looking for the suspect.

assoc_actor_2: Eastern Highlands Ethnic Group (Papua New Guinea); Men (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 14 October 2024, a man from Eastern Highlands was stripped naked and beaten up at 8-mile (Port Moresby, National Capital District) by a group of men from Enga then later abandoned at an area in Morata (Port Moresby, National Capital District) over being caught in the act of breaking and entering into an Engan family's home. The man was later assisted to the hospital by the police but later escaped and returned to his home in 8-mile. This incident then led to an ethnic clash (coded separately).

assoc_actor_1: Vigilante Group (Papua New Guinea); Pakia Communal Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Around 15 October 2024 (month of), Paika villagers held hostage a man for several days and torched his home at Pakia village in Pinei-Nari ward (Central Bougainville, Bougainville) after he said at a Pakia chief's funeral that him and his family members were sorcerers and that they were responsible for the late chief's death along with the deaths of other members in the community. Around 20 November, five of the victim's family members were rounded up and executed alongside the victim (coded separately). Two suspects of the murders were locked up by the Arawa police but a fight broke out after relatives demanded that the two should be released (coded separately).

assoc_actor_1: Eastern Highlands Ethnic Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 16 October 2024, a group of men from Eastern Highlands clashed with a group of men from Enga (coded as ethnic groups) at 8-mile (Port Moresby, National Capital District) in retaliation following an incident that occurred on 14 October (coded separately). There has been 1 confirmed fatality with several people injured.

On 18 October 2024, a group of men (likely to be from Enga based on a previous incident) attacked PMV bus drivers and PMV bus crew members at the Gordons bus stop (Port Moresby, National Capital District) after an incident that occurred the previous day between a PMV bus 16 and its crew members and an Engan street vendor that left the vendor seriously injured. Windscreens of about 20 PMV busses were damaged, and PMV busses route 17, 16 and 15 stopped operating after the fight but resumed operations the next day. The reason for the previous fight on Thursday is unknown.

On 19 October 2024, an elderly woman was killed by a group of men (likely to be from the Muntika tribe based on a call by the Provincial Police Commander Chief Superintendent to the tribe to surrender the suspects) in her own house at Nikinja village (coded to Baiyer Station, Mul-Baiyer, Western Highlands) then later victim's house was burned down with her in it before running away with some of her things. While the reason for killing the victim is unknown the Western Highlands Provincial Police Commander has called on the suspects to surrender themselves.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 22 October 2024, a 25 seater PMV bus carrying passengers travelling from Wabag to Sirunki, Laiagam, and Mulitaka, was ambushed and shot at by armed men from the Lyain clan, an ally of the Mulapin tribe near the Tambitanis Health Centre in Sirunki (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga), in retaliation to the killing of two Mulapin tribesmen (coded separately), resulting in 6 fatalities, 2 hospitalized with serious wounds, and 17 passengers who were missing but were later found by the police search and rescue team.

On 22 October 2024, locals from Western Highlands set up a roadblock at the border of Western Highlands and Enga (coded to Tomba, Tambul-Nebilyer), blocking off access into and out of Enga, in protest of the recent killing in Sirunki (coded separately), claiming that some Western Highlanders were also victims in the attack. The roadblock was removed by the police on Wednesday afternoon.

assoc_actor_1: Students (Papua New Guinea); Vigilante Group (Papua New Guinea)
assoc_actor_2: Students (Papua New Guinea); Women (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Around 23 October 2024 (week of), a group of male students armed with bush knives and sticks at Pausa Secondary School (Pausa, Wapenamanda, Enga), assaulted and stripped a fellow female student naked, after accusing her of having an affair with a teacher. A video of the incident then later circulated on social media. Last Thursday the Education Secretary condemned the incident and asked for a full investigation to which the principle of Pausa Secondary said decisions would be reached on 1 November 2024.

notes: On 26 October 2024, a widow's house was burned to the ground at Kamkumung, Peter Block, (Lae, Morobe) after a fight occurred between Eastern Highlanders and East Sepik settlers (coded as ethnic groups).

On 26 October 2024, armed men from the Ambulin tribe of Wapenamanda murdered a man from the Wakupin tribe at Aipipas village (Yaibos, Wapenamanda, Enga). The victim boarded a PMV bus at Birip that was travelling to Wapenamanda when the armed men stopped the bus, dragged the victim out and hacked him to death. The incident resulting in 1 fatality is connected to the tribal warfare that occurred in Wapenamanda between the Ambulin, Sikin and other allied tribes and was a breach in a peace accord that was signed earlier this year between the tribal leaders, Enga provincial administrator, and Police Commissioner David Manning in Port Moresby.

actor1: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-)
notes: Other: On 26 October 2024, leaders of the Moen tribe, whom the Lyain clan are a part of, surrendered 8 men at Sirunki (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) who were involved in the killing of 6 men in a 25-seater PMV bus last Tuesday (coded separately) to be taken into custody by the police. The perpetrators of the killings are from the Lyain clan. Police arrested seven suspects and announced that they will arrest the eighth man on a later date as he was sick.

assoc_actor_1: Farmers (Papua New Guinea); Labor Group (Papua New Guinea); Vigilante Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 26 October 2024, a man from Enga was chased and killed by vendors and farmers at Hagen Market (Hagen, Mount Hagen, Western Highlands) after he went around the market collecting illegal market fees from the vendors and farmers.

Around 30 October 2024 (week of), settlers from Goilala living at Vanapa village killed 3 people also from Goilala at Veikabu village. 2 weeks later another Goilala man was killed in retaliation at Vanapa, that led to a group of Goilala's attacking commuters and villagers along the Hiritano highway (coded separately).

On 2 November 2024, a fight which broke out between two families from Binasoa at Binasoa village in Haku ward (North Bougainville, Bougainville) led to the arrest of 36 people (coded separately), 4 seriously injured, and a Haku chief killed. One of the two families was the family of a sexual assault victim, and the other was the family of four suspects who were believed to have perpetrated the crime against the victim. The four suspects were previously tortured by the victim's family but the police intervened (coded separately).

actor1: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-)
notes: On 3 November 2024, 30 people from Binosoa were arrested at Binasoa village in Haku ward (North Bougainville, Bougainville) following a fight that occurred the previous day (coded separately) that resulted in 1 fatality, and 4 seriously injured.

On 3 November 2024, suspected security guards killed a 16-year-old boy at Hanta Mart Trading in Lae (Morobe) after he was caught in the act of shoplifting. The victim was taken to the back of the store where he was likely tortured (based on bruises on his body) then shot when he tried to escape. The security firm denies that their securities had anything to do with it since they claimed there was only one lone security that day and he was not allowed to the back of the store.

actor1: Police Forces of Papua New Guinea (2019-)
notes: Displacement: On 4 November 2024, thousands were displaced after settlers of Talai settlement were evicted and had their homes demolished by the police as ordered by the court at Section 120 Allotment 48, Port Moresby (Port Moresby, National Capital district). The settlers had guns pointed at them by police officers, whilst the police demolished and burned their houses. The Member for Port Moresby South has come out saying the eviction was illegal since there are no documents for the land and that the court must have been misinformed.

On 5 November 2024, a man was beaten up by members of the public and security guards at Nadzab in Gapsongkeg ward (Huon, Morobe). The man was a member of a gang who had held up a truck driver and had stolen his truck earlier that day, but he was later caught by members of the public who had the man beat up but he was later saved by the police.

assoc_actor_1: Maip Mulitaka Communal Group (Papua New Guinea)

notes: On 5 November 2024, a clash broke out between Mulitaka community members and PNG Defense Personnel at the Mulitaka landslip area (coded at Yambali, Lagaip-Porgera, Enga, the area affected by the landslide) after the locals set up a roadblock aimed at preventing traffic along the highway. This clash resulted in the destruction of several houses owned by locals. The State of Emergency controller and security personnel moved in to resolve the situation and open the road.

On 5 November 2024, settlers of Talai settlement held a protest at Badili, Port Moresby (National Capital District) after an eviction granted by the court was carried out at Talai settlement. The evection involved settlers having guns pointed at them by the police whilst their homes and properties were demolished, leaving thousands displaced (coded separately). The title of the land is still in question since the proper documents are missing.

assoc_actor_2: Mendi Ethnic Group (Papua New Guinea); Students (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Around 6 November 2024, a student from Mendi was attacked by Dauli locals during graduation at Dauli College of Higher Education at Komo-Hulia (coded to Dauli 1, Komo-Magarima, Hela) in retaliation to a shooting of their relative who was a grade 12 student, by the police. The victim survived the attack but is recovering. Meanwhile, the local leader has called on the suspects to surrender themselves.

On 7 November 2024, Passam villagers put up a roadblock at Passam Junction (Passam 1, Wewak, East Sepik) in the afternoon, following an incident that took place in the morning between passengers of a public motor vehicle and 10 armed men that resulted in damages being done to properties belonging to Passam villagers (coded separately). The villagers then gathered at the Passam police station and demanded K120,000, however, the police commander chief superintendent has demanded that the police and community leaders surrender the 10 armed men within 14 days.

On 7 November 2024, in the early hours of the morning, passengers on a public motor vehicle damaged a couple of properties belonging to Passam villages at the Passam junction (Passam 1, Wewak, East Sepik), as a retaliation after 10 armed men (likely to be from Passam based on the location of the event and the context) held the PMV bus at gun point. The bus driver scared off the man with the gun but the other armed men stoned the PMV bus then fled into the nearby villages. Following the incident villagers of Passam put up a roadblock in the afternoon (coded separately).

Around 8 November 2024 (week of), the Nomali and Aiyela (Aiyala) tribes of Porgera-Paiela signed a peace agreement to resolve their conflict at the Porgera Police station (Porgera, Lagaip-Porgera, Enga). The peace agreement was facilitated by the State of Emergency controller.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 10 November 2024, about 500 people held a 'Redvember Walk' protest in Port Moresby (National Capital District) to demand an end to gender-based violence. Amongst the people who marched was the family of a victim of a mugging attack last month at Tabari bus stop in Boroko that led to her death. The family demanded justice for their daughter as there were no updates on their daughter's attacker even though two suspects were apprehended.

On 13 November 2024, a group of people from Goilala living at Vanapa village attacked villagers and commuters along the Hiritano highway at Vanapa (Vanapa, Kairuku-Hiri, Central) after their relative was killed by a man also from Goilala that resided at Veikabu village (coded separately). The murder was a retaliation to the killing of 3 Goilala people at Veikabu two weeks ago (coded separately). The Goilala settlers at Veikabu also blocked the highway at Veikabu (coded separately). The provincial police commander warned both parties the next morning to refrain from taking the law into their own hands.

On 13 November 2024, Goilala settlers at Veikabu village blocked the road along the Hiritano highway at Veikabu (Vanapa ward, Kairuku-Hiri, Central) whilst the Goilala settlers at Vanapa attacked commuters and villages along the Hiritano highway (coded separately) after a Goilala man from Veikabu killed a Goilala man at Vanapa earlier that evening, in retaliation to the death of 3 Goilala people at Veikabu 2 weeks ago (coded separately). According to Veikabu community leaders, the Goilala group residing at village have lost more than 6 people this year whom they believe were killed by the other group living at Vanapa.

Other: On 13 November 2024, a man from Goilala living at Vanapa village was killed by a man also from Goilala that resided at Veikabu village along the Hiritano highway at Vanapa (Vanapa, Kairuku-Hiri, Central). The murder was a retaliation to the killing of 3 Goilala people at Veikabu two weeks ago (coded separately). The Goilala settlers at Veikabu also blocked the highway at Veikabu (coded separately). The provincial police commander warned both parties the next morning to refrain from taking the law into their own hands.

assoc_actor_1: Emai Communal Group (Papua New Guinea); Maunkwi Communal Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Around 13 November 2024 (week of), a fight broke out between a group from Koroba-Lake Kopiago of Hela Province living in Chimbu and villagers of Maunkwi and Emai villages of the Sina Sina-Yonggomugl district at Chimbu province (coded to Kundiawa Urban, Kundiawa-Gembogl) after a failed peace mediation and compensation ceremony. The Kundiawa police intervened and managed to stop the fight, rescuing 8 people who are from Kopiago, however, 1 man from Kopiago is missing, and 2 Kopiago men were dismembered resulting in 2 fatalities.

On 14 November 2024, villagers of Ainong had their village raided by a group of armed men from Womuk village at Ainong village, Simbai LLG (Middle Ramu, Madang), in retaliation, after the community had reported them to the authorities for producing homebrew, gambling, and disrupting the community. The villagers were chased, 21 of their homes looted and 14 were burned to the ground, leaving over 200 men, women, and children displaced and seeking refuge at the Anglican church. The villagers are unable to go back and rebuild due to threats being made by the same group.

Around 15 November 2024 (month of), two women were killed after being tortured and burned alive at Lagaip (coded to Aiyak, Lagaip-Porgera, Enga) over sorcery allegations. The victims were accused of killing a man in their community using sorcery. The perpetrators subjected the two women to prolonged torture, binding their bodies, gagging and blindfolding them before placing them inside a traditional highlands roundhouse, which was then set alight. By the time the police arrived, the perpetrators had already fled the scene.

As a result, the Kompiam District Hospital have closed operations for a week, whilst the police in Enga are in search for 15 suspects related to the shooting.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Around 11 February 2025 (month of), a fight took place between the Kaelibe clan of Wali Tarua LLG and the Poralin clan (coded as a tribal group as confirmed by locals) at Kompiam district (coded to Londor) (Enga). Following this, two men from the Poralin clan (coded as a tribal group as confirmed by locals) seeking treatment at Kompiam District Hospital were shot and killed by armed men from the Kaelibe clan, who snuck into the hospital (coded separately).

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Papua New Guinea); Teriye Clan Group (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 14 February 2025, a group of men from the Teriye clan in Imbonggu, Southern Highlands, forcibly entered the Paunda hydro-power facility at Paunda in Imbongu Rural LLG (coded to Kisenapoi, Imbonggu, Southern Highlands), protesting payment for work they had done three years ago. However, after further discussions among the parties involved, including the landowners, an understanding was reached. Power was restored to the Southern Highlands the following day, while PNG Power Limited has yet to provide an official response regarding the payment dispute.

Following the incident, the police carried out an eviction of settlers at Baruni settlement in the afternoon (coded separately). Investigations are still ongoing.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)

On 20 February 2025, members of the Correctional Services Tarangau Mothers Association and their supporters held a peaceful protest at the Bomana Camp in Port Moresby (National Capital District), calling for the reinstatement of the death penalty following the killing of a young mother by her soldier boyfriend at Murray Barracks on 8 February. The group, expressed concern over the suspect's lack of arrest, presented a petition urging the government to strengthen laws, including the return of the death penalty for murderers and rapists, and to improve collaboration among authorities in apprehending criminals. However, no government representatives were present to receive the petition, and the group indicated plans for further action if their concerns are not addressed within 21 days.

notes: On 27 February 2025, relatives of the police officer who had died of his injuries at Port Moresby General Hospital, after he and his colleagues were attacked at Mount Fire, Mendi last month (coded separately), staged a demonstration at Miles area, Mimanalo Local Level Government (coded to Kabiufa No.2, Goroka, Eastern Highlands) against the delay in police investigations into the incident that occurred. The relatives attacked and burned PMV buses and blocked roads from Mando to Five mile, causing movement and traffic on the Highlands highway to come to a halt. The relatives presented their petition to the Governor, urging the Southern Highlands leaders, Internal Security Minister, and Prime Minister to meet their demands or the Highlands Highway would be blocked off next Friday.

Around 27 February 2025 (week of), over 200 people from Enga convoying in 10 vehicles, who were relatives of an Engan teacher who was murdered during the week, were attacked by the public in Tari (Tari-Pori, Hela), after they had mistakenly thought the relatives from Enga were retaliating against them. The man's relatives from Enga had convoyed up to Tari to collect the body whilst dressed up in their traditional mourning attire and covered in mud to show their sorrow. Upon arriving the public thought, they were being attacked and started throwing stones at the Engans and in the process looted a store owned by Chinese nationals, however there was no report of casualties.

On 28 February 2025, relatives of victims in a car accident (likely villagers from Keltiga based on the location of the event) retaliated and blocked the highway at Keltiga (Mount Hagen, Western Highlands), after learning that two of their relatives had died in the car crash. The relatives blocked off the roads and damaged vehicles, however the police managed to quell the situation and reopen the highway.

On 1 March 2025, the owner of a PMV bus that was burned at Goroka during a demonstration on 27 February (coded separately), and his relatives demonstrated at Kindeng (coded to Kindeng 2, Anglimp-South Waghi, Jiwaka) demanding the Southern Highlands government replace his PMV bus within seven days. They held up a vehicle belonging to a trucking company from Southern Highlands in retaliation. After police intervention the truck was later released.

Following the 2 deaths, illegal miners burned mining equipment in retaliation and the next day the Sakar tribe dug out a ditch across the road connecting Laiagam to Porgera at Lyonge and cut down trees to close off road access (coded separately). The incident was a breach to the peace agreement signed in late January (coded separately).

On 3 March 2025, the Sakar tribe of Lyonge village closed off the national highway connecting Laiagam and Porgera at Lyonge (Lagaip-Porgera, Enga), after two illegal miners belonging to their tribe were shot by security forces at Porgera for attempting to break into a restricted Porgera facility, and engaging in a shootout with state security forces the previous day (coded separately). The Sakar tribe removed a culvert and dug a ditch 6 feet deep across the road and cut trees to place across the road. They were given 24 hours by the police to repair the road and to allow the public to access the road.

On 3 March 2025, a group from Kagua (Southern Highlands) living in Lae, fought with another group (likely to be from Nawae block as this is where the incident that sparked the fight took place) at Nawae block (Lae, Morobe), after a failed compensation meeting that resulted in two people being wounded and a house being burned. The conflict stemmed from an incident on the weekend, where a Kagua man's taxi was held up at Nawae block, and in retaliation, the taxi driver seriously injured one of the suspects. The police had intervened but the fight continued with a surprise attack on group from Kagua resulting in several houses belonging to the Kaguas being burned down.

Around 3 April 2025 (week of), Fowe and Rambau clans engaged in a fight at Siane Local Level Government (coded at Nomane, Chuave, Chimbu), due to the death of a Rambau man. The fight resulted in 3 fatalities.

Around 3 April 2025 (week of), two family factions fought with each other at Kinanka village in Sialum (Tewae-Siassi, Morobe), after youths from within the family had stolen two cows from their uncle, and one of them had later speared their uncle when the matter was reported to the village elders. The family split into two groups and fought with each other, resulting in 9 houses set ablaze, cash crops and gardens being destroyed. Five suspects were arrested but were later released after all parties involved had agreed to settle the matter outside of court. There were no casualties.

Among the abducted were a teacher and his wife, a community health worker and his wife, and five young women; a young teenage girl who was supposed to be the 10th victim, fought back and managed to escape, while a boy who was the 11th victim was sent back with the ransom demand. The security guard was stabbed after he refused to give the group K1, but got hit by a vehicle whilst he was running away from his attackers, leading to his death. The attack by the group from Wabag resulted in 4 fatalities, two being from Goilala Province, one from Eastern Highlands, and one from Enga. Around 21 May 2025 (between 19 - 22 May), the Puir and Murupe clans of Hupa signed a peace agreement at Hupa (Hupa Anda, Uba No. 12, Nipa-Kutubu, Southern Highlands), after 30 years of conflict. The clans agreed to the peace agreement after continuous peace mediation efforts from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the Mendi Catholic Diocese with the support of the United Kingdom and European Union. Many lives were lost, livelihood and property destroyed during the conflict, and over 5,000 people were displaced. Also, there to witness the peace agreement was the British High Commissioner to PNG, the head of United Kingdom Integrated Security Fund Pacific Programme, and the local leaders.

source: NBC Papua New Guinea; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 22 July 2025, Koiari land-owners led by two of their clan leaders held a sit in protest, at Rouna two (Depo (Mageri), Kairuku-Hiri, Central), to protest outstanding payments owed to them by the government. The Koiari land-owners threatened to cut the electricity and water supply into Port Moresby if their demands were not met, and proceeded to do so the next morning, but restored it again in the afternoon. However, the police have called the protest 'unlawful' after citing a complaint from Lower Koiari clans who argued that one of the protest leaders was not recognized under a 2013 National Executive Council (NEC) decision, that officially identified which landowner groups were entitled to compensation. Police investigations into the incident and those involved are still ongoing.

Authorities classified the incident as domestic terrorism and warned that those involved could face severe penalties under the new Domestic Terrorism Act

The argument escalated into a fight when the Engan group drove a vehicle into the Kabwum group's residence, hitting three of them, who were subsequently slashed with knives by the Engans. The fight resulted in 4 fatalities and the closure of schools, bringing surrounding communities to a standstill. Four individuals were later arrested - two from Kabwum and two from Enga.

On 11 August 2025, Tubusereia villagers staged a protest at Tubusereia junction (Kairuku-Hiri, Central) over compensation demands following a truck and 15-seater bus collision on 28 July that killed three people and injured 13 others. Police presence led the villagers to withdraw peacefully to their homes. Authorities warned against escalating the situation into ethnic conflict while investigations into the accident continued.

On 11 August 2025, a group of armed Fagululu youths burned more than 20 houses belonging to Fagululu villagers at Fagululu (Esa'ala, Milne Bay) and forced villagers to flee after the youths had an argument with a villager over prawn-diving rights at the Upawala river. On 13 August, the police entered the village to intervene but clashed with the group of youths who had set up an ambush for the police (coded separately). The incident has left residents displaced and hiding in surrounding areas.

Security measures: On 21 August 2025, the Enga Provincial Peace and Good Order Committee declared all districts of Enga Province, except Wabag, as official 'Fighting Zones' (coded at Wabag, Enga) in response to worsening tribal violence. The declaration, made under Section 4 of the Intergroup Fighting Act and set to remain in force for three months, empowered government agencies and security forces to impose emergency measures including curfews, liquor bans, restrictions on gatherings, random searches, and checkpoints. Authorities warned warring tribes to lay down arms and cooperate with peace efforts, while emphasizing that violators would face arrest, fines, and prosecution.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: Elections/referendum: On 4 September 2025, the first day of polling for the 2025 Autonomous Bougainville Government general election was held in the Atolls constituency, with voters casting their ballots as scheduled (coded to Buka, North Bougainville, Bougainville). Polling for other constituencies, North, South, and Central Bougainville, took place from 5 to 8 September 2025 in Bougainville and in locations outside the region, including Port Moresby, Lae, Madang, Kokopo, and the Eastern Highlands, to allow citizens living away from the Autonomous Region to participate. The election was extended in some areas due to missing names on the electoral roll and delayed delivery of ballot papers, but voting proceeded peacefully. On 6 October 2025, the writs for all 45 seats, including the presidency, 38 single-member constituencies, and six reserved regional seats for women and former combatants, were returned to the Speaker of the House of Representatives in accordance with Section 145 of the Bougainville Elections Act. A total of 408 candidates contested the election, including seven for the presidency. On 3 October 2025, incumbent President of the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, Ishmael Toroama, was declared the winner after receiving 90,443 votes, surpassing the absolute majority threshold.

Following the market clash, the group from Biangai raided the No.6 compound, destroying food gardens and burning houses belonging to people they believed were connected to the robbery (coded separately).

On 22 September 2025, groups from Biangai and Kataipa clashed at Wau main market (Wau Urban, Bulolo, Morobe) following the retaliatory killings the previous day of a Kataipa man at Wau Primary School junction (coded separately) and another man at Green Hill (coded separately), both suspected of involvement in an armed robbery earlier that day leaving three people dead (coded separately). During the clash, a teenager from Biaru was killed and an elderly woman sustained serious knife injuries. Police forces arrested 3 people from Kataipa. Afterward, Biangai landowners raided the No.6 Compound, destroyed food gardens, and burned homes where they believed the robbery suspects were hiding (coded separately).

Around 24 September 2025 (week of), tribesmen carried out an attack at Banz bus stop in Banz town (Banz, North Waghi, Jiwaka), after a fellow tribesman was killed by a bus crew for trying to force them to give him a fifty toea. After the news of his death reached the tribesmen, they travelled to Banz town in truck loads, prompted unrest, and killed two men.

Other: On 27 September 2025, a man from Gulf killed an Engan man at Moresby South, Port Moresby (National Capital District) that led to a retaliation the following day, when a group of Engans chased a group from Gulf out of their homes and burned 17 houses (coded separately).

On 28 September 2025, a group from Enga chased a group from Gulf out of their homes and burned their houses at Moresby South, Port Moresby (National Capital District) after an Engan man was killed by a man from Gulf the previous day (coded separately), resulting in 17 houses being burnt down. There were no injuries or fatalities.

On 1 October 2025, Nuigo settlers fought with Saksak settlers at Wewak (East Sepik) after two females from Nuigo who were students, were threatened by a masked man armed with a stapler (likely from Saksak compound since the Nuigo settlers retaliated against them). The crossfire between the two groups resulted in 3 fatalities.

The attack occurred after a court ruling over a piece of land went in favor of the company the contractors were working for and not the Baruni landowners.

On 20 October 2025, the Era and Kalubiagao tribes engaged in a tribal clash at Digine (coded at Munuma, Gumine, Chimbu) right after youths from the Era tribe attacked an off duty member of the PNG Defence Force (likely a member of the Kalubiagao tribe since that tribe got involved after the attack by the Era youths) while under the influence of alcohol. notes: Elections/referendum: On 27 October 2025, the two-week polling period for the nation's Local-Level Government elections began across all provinces except the National Capital District and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (coded to Lae, Morobe) to elect leaders for 375 LLGs and 6,916 wards. The counting was set to begin on 9 November, with writs initially due on 21 November, following two earlier deferrals linked to administrative issues. 15 provinces returned the writs on time. Due to delay in polling and counting in Western Highlands, Enga, Madang, Chimbu and Gulf, these provinces returned their writs on 28 November 2025. Writs for all seats for the LLG presidents were returned while 97% of the ward councilor seats were returned.

notes: On 29 October 2025, relatives of a Jiwaka man who was beheaded earlier in the month gathered at the Central Police Headquarters in Gordon, Port Moresby (National Capital District) to protest and demand justice, and clarity around the circumstances of their father's death. The family submitted a petition seeking K500,000 in customary compensation and called for authorities to explain the circumstances surrounding his death, as well as pursue accountability and reconciliation processes. They gave Central Governor Rufina Peter five days to respond, and addressed the petition to provincial and district leaders and community representatives.

Around 29 October 2025 (week of), Genoka residents clashed at a polling booth at Genoka (Goroka Urban, Eastern Highlands) during the 2025 Local-Level Government elections in Eastern Highlands province. The confrontation escalated from a fistfight into stone-throwing and stick attacks, leading police to intervene and take one injured person to hospital. The violence suspended polling at the location as tensions rose among voters hoping to cast their ballots.

On 30 October 2025, a male council candidate and two men destroyed ballot papers at a polling station at Vanapa Brown, (Vanapa, Kairuku-Hiri, Central), disrupting the voting process during the 2025 Local-Level Government elections. Police arrested the three men and detained them, to be charged under the Election Offences Act.

notes: On 30 October 2025, gunmen from the Yakuman tribe attacked rival Yangakuni tribes during the local level government polling at Takaipos village, (Wapenamanda, Enga) and shot indiscriminately at innocent tribes: Kiakae, Yambalekin, Kana, Anjin, Taekin, Waipalin, Yatikin, Manga, Tokopitan, Yana, Kalokoe, Napukin, Sini, and Kuta tribes of the Lower Lai, including Itoken (coded as Itiokon clan, as confirmed by locals on the ground), who were present to cast their votes, leading to 2 fatalities and several other admitted to the hospital. The attack sparked retaliatory clashes from the Yangakuni tribe joined by Itoken tribe, as allies, during which three staff houses at the Mambisanda Emmanuel Lutheran Hospital were burned since the Yakuman tribesmen lived among them. The main hospital facilities remained unharmed and combined security forces were deployed to protect the area. The reason behind the attack was suspected to be related to tribal conflicts.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)

Police intervened to restore order, and polling at the affected venue was postponed and completed the following day. Similar election related incidents occurred at Tambul-Nebilyer and Mount Hagen districts (coded separately)

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea)
notes: On 4 November 2025, voters and supporters hurled stones at each other at the polling site near Kagamuga Airport area (Kagamuga Urban, Mount Hagen, Western Highlands), during LLG polling for ward three. The clashes disrupted voting, and airport security, along with the police intervened to contain the situation. Disturbances were also reported at Fish Pond, Popes Oval, and New Town in Mt Hagen, prompting authorities to relocate polling to the nearby airport police station. The reason behind throwing the stones was unclear.

The attack triggered retaliatory violence by Urugen villagers the following day where they attacked the Kinim police station and killed 2 suspects who were detained, and burned sections of Gial village (coded separately).

notes: On 8 November 2025, locals from Ato market area and students from the University of Goroka fought at Ato Market (Goroka Urban, Goroka, Eastern Highlands) after a student from Western Highlands province living at Ato market area was harassed and attacked by locals while on his way to a function at the university after he refused to give them money. The fight escalated when the university students retaliated against the locals. Police were outnumbered and couldn't contain the fight, however the fight stopped due to heavy rain, but continued the next day, resulting in at least 46 injuries including 40 students, 3 locals, and 3 police officers, while a few university property were damaged including police vehicles (coded separately).

source: Post Courier; Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary; The National (Papua New Guinea); TVWAN
notes: On 9 November 2025, locals from Ato market and University of Goroka students fought at the University of Goroka (Goroka Urban, Goroka, Eastern Highlands), following a fight that occurred the previous day after a student from Western Highlands province residing at Ato market area was attacked by locals while he was on his way to attend a function at the University, prompting the university students to retaliate (coded separately). The fight resumed when locals regrouped and attacked university property and students, resulting in retaliation from the students that led to a fight lasted from morning till noon. Police in the province were outnumbered but managed to stop the fight when reinforcements from Chimbu and Western Highlands went up to help. At least 46 people were injured including 40 students, 3 locals, and 3 police officers, while a few university property were damaged including police vehicles. Provincial governments from the upper highlands and Morobe began evacuating students from their home provinces on Monday and Tuesday.

On 9 November 2025, supporters from the Kirapan tribe led by a public servant running for the Kompiam LLG presidency ambushed the convoy of the sitting Kompiam LLG president at a location near Wabag (coded at Wabag, Enga), while he was travelling from Kompiam Station, fatally shooting his wife. The suspect, who had recently been declared councilor for the Kirapan tribe, mobilized his tribesmen to carry out the attack.

source: Post Courier; The National (Papua New Guinea); TVWAN
notes: On 11 November 2025, members of the Wanigela community fought at Kupiano Station in Abau District (Kupiano Urban) (Central) during the counting of LLG election votes, leaving an elderly man seriously injured. Additional police units were deployed to contain the situation, and counting was temporarily postponed, since the fight was election related.

On 11 November 2025, a fight broke out between two groups of men from Tari at Nine Mile, Port Moresby (National Capital District), leaving one of their members injured. The following day, the groups fought again under the Erima Flyover Bridge, damaging market stalls and prompting police intervention (coded separately). The motive of the fight is not known.

On 12 November 2025, two groups of men from Tari, engaged in a retaliatory fight at Erima Flyover Bridge, Port Moresby (National Capital District) after a clash that occurred the previous day at Nine Mile left one of their members injured (coded separately). During the violence, market stalls were damaged, prompting police to respond quickly and arrest 31 men, including two community leaders who were released to help identify others involved. The motive behind the initial clash was not known.

notes: On 21 November 2025, relatives of a losing candidate in the LLG elections killed the previous day by the newly elected councilor's brother (coded separately), carried out retaliation attacks against the family of the elected councilor at Waipeng village, Kitiga ward (Mount Hagen, Western Highlands). The retaliation resulted in the death of 4 people, including the father of the newly elected councilor, 1 seriously injured, and the burning of over 20 houses. 6 suspects were arrested.

On 21 November 2025, the Yakuman and Yangakuni tribes of Wapenamanda signed a peace agreement at Port Moresby (National Capital District), aimed at ending the ongoing conflict that began in August (coded separately). The agreement required both tribes to hand over individuals responsible for previous violence within seven days, allowing police to investigate and hold perpetrators accountable. The peace process, signed by local leaders for the Yangakuni and Yakuman tribes, followed a conflict that claimed more than 30 lives and caused extensive property damage, with previous attempts at mediation stalled due to disagreements and logistical challenges.

The attack occurred the day after a peace agreement was signed between the Yangakuni and Yakuman tribes (coded separately). Homes were attacked and set ablaze, while a number of people were injured and killed. In response, the Yakuman tribe blocked the Wabag Highway (coded separately), prompting the Yangakuni tribe to also block sections of the highway. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 23 November 2025, villagers of Voda and Linasasa engaged in a fight at Wasu Rural LLG (coded to Sio 2) (Tewae-Siassi, Morobe). The fight reignited the next day after a failed peace mediation (coded separately) when villagers from Sio attacked areas within Voka and Linasasa, causing widespread property damage, arson attacks and attempted murder. While the root cause of the fight is still not known, a failed out-of-court settlement held on 2 December to settle the incident, led to the arrest of a key suspect who later died of a stroke in police custody, prompting his relatives to retaliate against the police (coded separately).

On 25 November 2025, leaders of Vunamurmur and Bitabaur wards of Raluana LLG held a traditional peace ceremony at Bitabaur Community Hall (Bitabaur, Kokopo, East New Britain), ending years of conflict. Traditional shell money were traded amongst the two wards as sign of peace and end to the conflict between the two groups. The peace ceremony was witnessed by neighboring communities, and initiated by ward councilors, local leaders, and church leaders

The state security forces intervened and arrested 18 men from the Yakuman tribe, arrested for not surrendering suspects involved in the initial fight between the Yakuman and the Yangakuni tribe (coded separately), prompting the Yakuman tribe to block off the Lai bridge, however, the state security forces removed the blockade.

On 10 December 2025, residents of Lavongai local-level government (LLG) gathered to witness their local leaders sign a peace and restoration treaty at Tsoi Island (Kavieng, New Ireland), to end years of conflict amongst the people of Lavongai LLG, that had caused violence, displacement of families and disruption to education.
